reviewText: This is a great concept, but the game as it is leaves me with a nagging impression that the people who developed don't actually speak English. There are a great number of highly questionable synonyms".\n\nFurthermore
date: the display seems to have a frustrating tendency to glitch out\n\nLastly the claim that the game is narrated by Richard Dawkins is patently false as there is no narration."

reviewText: I can't recommend this game. It's true that I'm not exactly english for a start, so playing an english-based word game is tricky, but it doesn't matter, really. That game fails to do what it claims to do in the first place.\n\nThe rules are simple : you're given a target word (say Silence")
recommended: and a cloud of synonyms you can pick from. The goal is to get closer and closer to the target word by picking the right words from the words cloud. The thing is
hoursPlayed: there's not only synonyms in the cloud
voteText: but also antonyms
helpfulPercent: sometimes just analog terms (otherwise you wouldn't get very far)... but not always.\n\nSo for example starting with "Crash"
votesHelpful: goind towards "Silence" you could expect to go through "Crack"
votesFunny: and then choose the antonym "Silence"... but only IF the game knows that "Silence" is an antonym of "Noise". but when you get
column16: to the word "Real" you can choose "Lawful"... and also "Unlawful"
column17: but can't pick "Silence" out of "Noise".\n\nAnd there you have it : this game is not about knowing your english
column18: it's about guessing what words are linked with what other words in the game's database. And without knowing what dictionary it was built onto
column19: there's NO WAY you could play this game properly.\n\nThis is more a data mesh exploration game than a word game. Therefore it is pretty bad. I know it's cheap
column20: but that doesn't make it any better"

reviewText:
Really fun game that provokes a stimulating fluidity of thought... for mobile devices... ported to the PC... terribly.
If you're someone who reads a thesaurus for fun or would like to exercise your vocabulary, I definitely recommend grabbing this game. Being a mobile game at heart it's great for those pick-up-and-put-down sessions when you can't commit to something meatier. However, you may just want to pass on this PC port and simply get the mobile version as the PC version gets little in the way of love. A great example of this is when you enter your initials for a high score, you have to click the letters to cycle through the alphabet instead of simply typing them them with the keyboard. Womp-womp. At the price, this portitis can easily be overlooked.

Edit: ICYMI (like me) All profits from Synonymy got [sic] to Educational Charities
date: including the Richard Dawkins Foundation." and "the foundation’s mission is to realize Richard’s vision to remove the influence of religion in science education and public policy
recommended: and eliminate the stigma that surrounds atheism and non-belief." I imagine some people would not like the cut of that jive and it's not written anywhere on the tin."
voteText: true
votesHelpful: 30 of 38 people (79%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: Synonym is a game in which you attempt to use multiple definitions of words to move from synonym to synonym to link two words which are disparate in their general meanings. It is an interesting concept, and can be neat to explore the word-map, but ultimately there's not much to the game - each pair is self-contained and there is no progression from challenge to challenge, so once you've gone through a single time there's not much variety (beyond the definitions in question, of course).\n\nTo someone who greatly enjoys words and reading, this might scratch an itch. But it's a very niche game without much in the way of replayability, so it is difficult to recommend to the general consumer.
voteText: 33 of 44 people (75%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
As an idea, it's brilliant.  I love words and I like connecting the chain from one to another.

As a game, it's not so great.  Some obvious synonyms are missing, some connections are made that I don't think work ... essentially, skill is eliminated.

Buy this to explore words and you should get some enjoyment out of it; however, I have a feeling most people, looking for a game, would simply be disappointed.

reviewText:
An interesting puzzle game that varies in difficulty during your seemingly randomly generated paths throught the pages of the virtual thesarus.

Recommended for people who want to challenge their brain for a moment. Game can get tedious if you find yourself lost,  but there are audio ques that help guide you in the right direction.

If you are bored easily, there isn't much else to get you to invest time in the game. It's basically flipping through words until you find a word that you need. Not much in terms of gameplay, but entertaining nevertheless for those who want a mental excercise.

The price is extremely cheap, $2 at the time of writing, so you aren't missing much after purchasing. Might as well, you or a family member might enjoy it!  There is a multiplayer aspect that is explained in the trailer, and it's entertaining.

reviewText:
Synonymy is a game where you are given a starting word and you have to travel trough synonyms of synonyms trying to reach the goal word that you are also given at the start.

The game has a difficulty selection, making it enjoyable to people of all ages. The easiest difficulty usually gives you very common words, where the paths are more obvious. But on the hardest difficulty, the words start to be a little more complex, not so common, making it challenging for older people. Since you can see the definition of every single word it's a very educational game - even for adults - you may learn a word or two that you didn't know before, specially on the harder difficulty settings.

You probably won't play this game for hours and hours in a row but rather on short bursts of time several times.

The game also features seeds" (or pass-codes)
date: a 5 character code that you and your friends can enter on the beginning of the game to ensure you have the same starting word and goal. That way you can compare your scores at the end.\nThere's also a global leaderboard
recommended: where you can see the the score
hoursPlayed: starting and goal words of the most recently played games around the world
voteText: along with its pass-code in case you want to try the same challenge by yourself.\n\nI absolutely recommend it. It is very cheap too. Get it."
votesFunny: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText: It's fun to play when you want to give your brain a jog. You match synonyms starting with a random word trying to get to a different random word. Although it really should be updated and have a few more words, for the most part it's got the basic synonyms already there. The interface is a bit clunky, but not bad. The sounds are fitting for the game and blend well. Overall, give it a shot if you think it's worth a few bucks.

reviewText:
==== Review ====Synonymy is about creating a chain of synonyms in order to link your starting word with a goal word. This original idea had so much potential to become a fun word game, but instead is just a tedious exercise of clicking. At least with some sort of graphic to show progression or a story of some kind would have made this so much better. As it is, Synonymy is the only game of its kind so its uniqueness may appeal to some.

==== Score ====Average
- 5/10

reviewText: This game benefits by making one's vocabulary larger that is especially helpful for me who isn't a native speaker. Its gimmick is interactivity: all these leaderboards, championships, retweets etc. look like they're a natural and logic-based part of the game, not just an attempt to follow today's social network craze. Indeed, it is a good reason to communicate through learning and playing, and I'd like to see this game translated in other languages, as it's planned, to make its educational value even bigger, going beyond the English-speaking world. The bad is, that the game is obviously made for mobile devices in the first place, so this PC port isn't as great as we'd like to see it. Still, this game, even as it is, is definitely worth trying.

reviewText:
== Updated for version 3.0 ==

Synonymy is an interesting thought experiment in game form. However, I found that it gets old quickly and the enjoyment fades in about an hour. 3.0 is a major improvement, though, and it's good to see that progress has been made. I didn't run into any glitches this time around and the game was much more achievable.

Still, Richard Dawkins actually does not narrate the whole game, just the tutorial. I'm convinced that this game is polarizing -- either you really like the concept and can play it forever, or play one or two rounds and are done with it. In my opinion, most people are probably in the second camp.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The app is so broken and frustrating that it's not worth trying. No full screen mode, no settings, incredibly annoying audio, and the display doesn't even render at the correct aspect ratio unless you manually tweak the window to exactly the right size.

The window popped up mostly off the screen, and it was too large for my 1080p display. I went to try to find the settings for this but there don't seem to be any. Clicking around left me very frustrated as there's a long & terribly annoying noise that plays every time you click something. The UI metaphors are completely nonstandard and both confusing and clunky.

I finally figured out that the only option is to play in a window that you have manually resized so that the content area of the window has exactly the right aspect ratio. I don't think these issues are because of bugs: it's just because they weren't trying and/or have no clue about modern UI conventions.

So I'm taking the rather extreme position that this isn't worth trying just because the interface and rendering engine is so terrible. It really should have just been a browser application: there's nothing here that requires a native application: running this in a browser would have made it work *much* better.

reviewText:
Positive:
Inexpensive and a good mental exercise for wordsmiths or aspiring wordsmiths who know exactly what they're getting into. Try to find a chain of synonyms that connect two dissimilar words.

Negatives/Gripes:
It's come to my attention that any profit goes to a specific charity you may not want to support. Given how less than forthcoming the store page is with this information, that's incredibly bad. For this reason and this reason alone I cannot in good conscious give this game any favorable recommendation.

This is a game you can play by yourself if you have a thesaurus and the will to challenge yourself or someone else to chain together any two words of your choice. Why does this need to be electronic, other than the fact that most people don't own a thesaurus? Give us something, developer. (I am aware of the scores, challenges, etc? - but I do not acknowledge these as things of value to most people)

Store page claims narrated" by some guy. That might apply to the TRAILER
date: but I have yet to hear one word of narration in game.\n\nLaunches in a window as large as my screen
recommended: but off-center such that I can't see everything. Can maximize the window but the bottom is still behind the taskbar unless I change my taskbar settings for this one game. No options to my knowledge for changing screen size to something more convenient - not even true full screen.\n\nSomething unpleasant happend the first time I tried to open the menus - the instruction text remained
hoursPlayed: as if on a bottom layer
voteText: and every menu text in historical order layered on top
helpfulPercent: AFTER I had resumed the game. The result was an impossible-to-read/play eye-sore. Closed the game and had to restart (avoiding menus from now on after I start a game).\n\nSeems primarily designed for touch devices and is minimalistic in many ways. Lack of controls and conveniences that should be simple enough for a mouse/keyboard make for an unneccessarily punishing
votesFunny: you can see definitions for the word that is your final objective before you start
commentsCount:
but that's it. I didn't see much opportunity to learn anything in this game. It's no more educational than any dictionary.

Example of what I mean:
When you pick a synonym
column16: the previous word is usually listed on the first page. Instead of being able to "undo" a word and try a different synonym
column17: the game just keeps adding your choices together. So when you finally complete the "word chain" you can end up with the exact same word appearing several times. For a game that automatically posts every word chain completed to the web
column18: I would have thought it respectful to anyone following those posts if the game bothered to post only the most direct path - NOT every single redundant instance of someone fumbling around in search of the end."

reviewText:
This game is interesting! I love the concept of taking two totally unrelated words and connecting them through synonyms. Unfortunately, that idea isn't executed as thoroughly as it could (and maybe should) be. What I mean is when you're choosing synonyms, you only have a handful of choices, rather than the entire gamut of synonyms for a particular word. I can only think this was done to make the game simpler, but why would a game dev ever think that'd be a good idea? Laziness? Pretension? Who knows!
This game is already niche, so cater to it & make it complex! ALAS!

THAT SAID... Synonymy is a fun little brain game, especially if you're a language person, & especially if it's on sale, but don't expect too much.
